review.title: Fuzzy Object-Oriented Dynamic Networks. II
review.abstract: This article generalizes object-oriented dynamic networks to the fuzzy case, which allows one to represent knowledge on objects and classes of objects that are fuzzy by nature and also to model their changes in time. Within the framework of the approach described, a mechanism is proposed that makes it possible to acquire new knowledge on the basis of basic knowledge and considerably differs from well-known methods used in existing models of knowledge representation. The approach is illustrated by an example of construction of a concrete fuzzy object-oriented dynamic network.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: Currently, one of the most important problems in the field of knowledge representation is the generalization of knowledge representation models (KRMs) to the fuzzy case using a powerful tool such as Fuzzy Sets [1]. The necessity of this generalization is dictated by the fact that the body of knowledge available to man is inaccurate, incomplete or diffuse in one sense [2]. Since Fuzzy Sets are an efficient apparatus for modeling objects and processes of this kind, it is useful to generalize and use KRMs. There are many similar generalizations, especially Fuzzy Logic, Fuzzy Semantic Networks, Fuzzy Production Models, Fuzzy Neural Networks, Fuzzy Ontologies, Fuzzy Frames, Fuzzy UML, etc. First of all, these KRMs are theoretical models that can be implemented practically within the framework of concrete intelligent information systems (IISs).

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: This paper presents the conception of the object-oriented approach to the representation of blurred knowledge. It proposes the generalization of object-oriented dynamic networks to the blurred case. The representation of blurred knowledge is illustrated by an example of the construction of a blurred object-oriented dynamic network for some classes of blurred convex polygons. The described approach allows to represent blurred knowledge and to model its changes over time and also represents a mechanism for obtaining new knowledge from basic knowledge; this mechanism is very different from known methods of acquiring knowledge in existing RMs.
